para: &nodes; that are pinned will not move during &skel; modification operations. Pinning &nodes; is one way of restricting the scope of future &skel; modifications.

For example, some &nodes; may be already positioned on a material boundary, but the shapes of the &elems; in the interior of the material may need to be improved. shows the results of smoothing a &skel; with and without pinned nodes.

caption.para: A &skel; that has been partially adapted to the underlying µ.
The result of smoothing the &skel; with the &nodes; on the boundary of the circle pinned. (Smoothing was done for 5 iterations with alpha=0.3.)
The result of smoothing the &skel; without first pinning the &nodes; on the boundary of the circle. Notice that the boundary is much less well resolved than it had been.

note.para: Whether or not a &node; is pinned for the purpose of &skel; modifications has no bearing on whether or not it will move when a &mesh; is solved. That depends on the boundary conditions and the value of the displacement &field;. &node; pinning applies only to &skel; modifications.
